channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-2126] Fuse 6.1 Rollup up breaks HTTP proxy support for access to remote Maven repository
item.description: Installation of Rollup 1 on top of Fuse 6.1.0 GA appears to prevent proper access to remote Maven repositories via an HTTP proxy, leading to various issues both during, and after, installation of this patch.
item.environment: JBoss Fuse 6.1.0 GA, Squid Proxy, Fedora 20 in an environment with no Internet access
item.summary: Fuse 6.1 Rollup up breaks HTTP proxy support for access to remote Maven repository

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
According to what I see in the code, the following setting in $FUSE_HOME/etc/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.cfg should work:

org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.proxies=http:host=xxx,port=xxx,user=xxx,pass=xxx,nonProxyHosts=HOST1,HOST2,HOST3;https:host=xxx,port=xxx,user=xxx,pass=xxx,nonProxyHosts=HOST1,HOST2,HOST3

Hmm, I can't tell you much about ENTESB-1558...
When I see in the Fabric8/master code, I see that nonProxyHosts is used: https://github.com/fabric8io/fabric8/blob/master/fabric/fabric-maven/src/main/java/io/fabric8/maven/util/MavenConfigurationImpl.java#L433
And the used PID is still org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn: https://github.com/fabric8io/fabric8/blob/master/fabric/fabric-agent/src/main/java/io/fabric8/agent/DeploymentAgent.java#L318

See here to get the names of properties which must be set for proxy configuration.

And here's my io.fabric8.maven PID:

remoteRepositories=${profile:io.fabric8.agent/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.repositories}
 
updatePolicy=always
 
appendSystemRepos=false
 
proxyProtocol=http
 
proxyHost=javelin.everfree.forest
 
proxyPort=3128
 
proxyUsername=fuse
 
proxyPassword=fuse
 
nonProxyHosts=localhost

I think I have to check the nonProxyHosts scenario (didn't do it yet).

summary

We have two PIDs:

  • io.fabric8.maven - used for fabric-maven-proxy bundle which sets up a web application acting as maven proxy. This proxy is then prepended to the list of repositories used by fabric-agent. So all fabric related downloads (like profile-edit, container-add-profile, ...) will use this.
  • org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn - used for pax-url-mvn URL handled used for example by osgi:install or features:addurl

To add to the confusion:

  • I fixed Fabric8 (upstream, for Fuse 6.2) to use external settings.xml for maven/http-proxy configuration
  • Guillaume has modified the maven-related code to get rid of some duplications.

So sorry Kevin for the confusion I brought...
So as Paolo Antinori described in ENTESB-1558, to make nonProxyHosts work set correct system property in Fuse start/setenv scripts.
and for the scenario in the description, you have to change:

fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.host=squid.corp.redhat.com fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.port=3128 fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.protocol=http fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid 'io.fabric8.maven/proxy.nonProxyHosts=192.*|127.*|localhost|localhost.localdomain' fabric

to

fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxyHost=squid.corp.redhat.com fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxyPort=3128 fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxyProtocol=http fabric
 
fabric:profile-edit --pid 'io.fabric8.maven/nonProxyHosts=192.*|127.*|localhost|localhost.localdomain' fabric

Sorry, jboss-fuse is private repository. Here's Fabric8 equivalent:

List of io.fabric8.maven PID proxy-related property names: https://github.com/fabric8io/fabric8/blob/fabric8-1.1.0.CR5/fabric/fabric-maven-proxy/src/main/java/io/fabric8/maven/impl/MavenProxyRegistrationHandler.java#L94-L105

I created an important bug: ENTESB-2171 - hawtio's maven indexer temporarily (for the time it takes to fetch the index, which may be several minutes at least) disables JVM support for http proxies! It just removes system properties like http.proxyHost and http.proxyPort.
Ouch!

After my fix to hawtio-maven-indexer, I got first success in my setup:

squid logs:

1415271296.887      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 4180 GET http://repository.jboss.org/nexus/content/repositories/ea/.index/nexus-maven-repository-index.properties - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415271313.042    524 192.168.122.108 TCP_MISS/200 827 GET http://repository.jboss.org/nexus/content/repositories/ea/.index/nexus-maven-repository-index.properties fuse HIER_DIRECT/10.5.105.47 text/plain
 
1415271340.331  13926 192.168.122.108 TCP_MISS/200 14855098 GET http://repository.jboss.org/nexus/content/repositories/ea/.index/nexus-maven-repository-index.gz fuse HIER_DIRECT/10.5.105.47 application/x-gzip
 
1415271393.547    382 192.168.122.108 TCP_MISS/200 1679 GET http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/.index/nexus-maven-repository-index.properties fuse HIER_DIRECT/199.27.76.209 text/plain
 
1415271546.579 129583 192.168.122.108 TCP_MISS/200 146898488 GET http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/.index/nexus-maven-repository-index.gz fuse HIER_DIRECT/199.27.76.209 application/octet-stream

fuse logs:

11:53:44,418 | INFO  | de startup timer | MavenIndexerFacade               | 250 - io.hawt.hawtio-maven-indexer - 1.2.0.redhat-379 | Updating the maven indices. This may take a while, please be patient...
 
...
 
12:03:59,178 | INFO  | de startup timer | MavenIndexerFacade               | 250 - io.hawt.hawtio-maven-indexer - 1.2.0.redhat-379 | Completed updating 2 maven indices.

Here's my setup for completeness (all host names available in /etc/hosts):

VM1 (squid http proxy, IP=192.168.122.102, hostname="javelin"|"javelin.everfree.forest")

No TCP connections (new) allowed to node1 and node2). Allow TCP connections to SQUID Proxy

iptables -I OUTPUT_direct -d 192.168.122.108 -p tcp -m state --state new -j REJECT
 
iptables -I OUTPUT_direct -d 192.168.122.109 -p tcp -m state --state new -j REJECT
 
iptables -A IN_public_allow -p tcp --dport 3128 -j ACCEPT

VM2 (Fuse node1, IP=192.168.122.108, hostname="node1"|"node1.example.com")

No outbound TCP connections on ports 80 and 443, allow connection to hawtio console, allow all TCP traffic from node2

iptables -I OUTPUT 1 -p tcp --dport 80 -j REJECT
 
iptables -I OUTPUT 1 -p tcp --dport 443 -j REJECT
 
iptables -I INPUT 1 -s 192.168.122.109 -j ACCEPT
 
iptables -I INPUT 1 -p tcp --dport 8181 -j ACCEPT

VM3 (Fuse node2, IP=192.168.122.109, hostname="node2"|"node2.example.com"))

No outbound TCP connections on ports 80 and 443, allow all TCP traffic from node1

iptables -I OUTPUT 1 -p tcp --dport 80 -j REJECT
 
iptables -I OUTPUT 1 -p tcp --dport 443 -j REJECT
 
iptables -I INPUT 1 -s 192.168.122.108 -j ACCEPT

Changes to clean Fuse 6.1.GA (379). No patch applied yet

node1, bin/setenv

export JAVA_MAX_MEM=1024M
 
export JAVA_MAX_PERM_MEM=512M

node1, bin/karaf

(easier debugging)

DEFAULT_JAVA_DEBUG_OPTS="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=y,address=5005"

node1, etc/system.properties

This is to make osgi:install work

http.proxyUser=fuse
 
http.proxyPassword=fuse
 
http.proxyHost=javelin
 
http.proxyPort=3128
 
http.nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*
 
https.proxyUser=fuse
 
https.proxyPassword=fuse
 
https.proxyHost=javelin
 
https.proxyPort=3128
 
https.nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*

node1, etc/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.cfg

This is used by "mvn://" PAX URL handler

org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.proxySupport=true
 
org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.proxies=http:host=javelin,port=3128,user=fuse,pass=fuse,nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*;https:host=javelin,port=3128,user=fuse,pass=fuse,nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*

The above is enough to make osgi:install work behind authenticated proxy:

Fuse console:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> install mvn:org.apache.commons/commons-dbcp2/2.0
 
Bundle ID: 251

squid logs

1415272682.198    889 192.168.122.108 TCP_CLIENT_REFRESH_MISS/200 167758 GET http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/commons/commons-dbcp2/2.0/commons-dbcp2-2.0.jar fuse HIER_DIRECT/23.235.46.209 application/java-archive

Now fabric:create.

The only request that went via proxy was (squid logs):

1415273241.656    393 192.168.122.108 TCP_MISS/200 500 GET http://freegeoip.net/json/ fuse HIER_DIRECT/168.235.149.225 application/json

Requests for Git (http://node1.example.com:8181/git/fabric/info/refs?service=git-upload-pack) went using java.net.Proxy=DIRECT

Another issue... After fabric:create, org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn PID is replaced by the one from default profile, so you have to update it with proxy settings. I did it via hawtio by adding:

org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.proxySupport=true
 
org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.proxies=http:host=javelin,port=3128,user=fuse,pass=fuse,nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*;https:host=javelin,port=3128,user=fuse,pass=fuse,nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*

to /wiki/branch/1.0/view/fabric/profiles/default.profile/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.properties

Something fishy is going here... After I updated the above PID, I saw the following in the logs:

javax.security.auth.login.FailedLoginException: User doesn't exist
 
	at io.fabric8.jaas.ZookeeperLoginModule.login(ZookeeperLoginModule.java:134)
 
	at org.apache.karaf.jaas.boot.ProxyLoginModule.login(ProxyLoginModule.java:83)[karaf-jaas-boot.jar:]
 
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor26.invoke(Unknown Source)
 
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.invoke(LoginContext.java:762)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.access$000(LoginContext.java:203)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext$4.run(LoginContext.java:690)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext$4.run(LoginContext.java:688)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.invokePriv(LoginContext.java:687)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.login(LoginContext.java:595)[:1.7.0_72]
 
	at io.fabric8.git.http.GitSecureHttpContext.doAuthenticate(GitSecureHttpContext.java:143)[102:io.fabric8.fabric-git-server:1.0.0.redhat-379]
 
	at io.fabric8.git.http.GitSecureHttpContext.handleSecurity(GitSecureHttpContext.java:96)[102:io.fabric8.fabric-git-server:1.0.0.redhat-379]
 
	at org.ops4j.pax.web.service.jetty.internal.HttpServiceServletHandler.doHandle(HttpServiceServletHandler.java:68)[100:org.ops4j.pax.web.pax-web-jetty:3.0.6]
 
...

a quick glance (debug) showed me that client (JGit) sends fuse/fuse as credentials!

Here's a quick tcpdump -A -i lo 'tcp port 8181 and host node1':

REQUEST:
 
GET /git/fabric/info/refs?service=git-receive-pack HTTP/1.1
 
Accept-Encoding: gzip
 
Pragma: no-cache
 
User-Agent: JGit/1.0.0.redhat-379
 
Accept: application/x-git-receive-pack-advertisement, */*
 
Cache-Control: no-cache
 
Host: node1.example.com:8181
 
Connection: keep-alive
 
 
 
RESPONSE:
 
 
 
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
 
WWW-Authenticate: Basic realm="karaf"
 
Content-Length: 0
 
Server: Jetty(8.1.14.v20131031)

This is ok, as JGit doesn't do preemptive basic auth.

But look now:

GET /git/fabric/info/refs?service=git-receive-pack HTTP/1.1
 
Accept-Encoding: gzip
 
Pragma: no-cache
 
User-Agent: JGit/1.0.0.redhat-379
 
Accept: application/x-git-receive-pack-advertisement, */*
 
Cache-Control: no-cache
 
Host: node1.example.com:8181
 
Connection: keep-alive
 
Authorization: Basic ZnVzZTpmdXNl

base64("fuse:fuse") == ZnVzZTpmdXNl

I don't know what sets the Authorization Header...

When I debug (much lesser chance to have race condition), I see the following is being sent:

GET /git/fabric/info/refs?service=git-receive-pack HTTP/1.1
 
Accept-Encoding: gzip
 
Pragma: no-cache
 
User-Agent: JGit/1.0.0.redhat-379
 
Authorization: Basic Y29udGFpbmVyI3Jvb3Q6Vk45Z0RvR0Nudkw3SHRnSg==
 
Accept: application/x-git-receive-pack-advertisement, */*
 
Cache-Control: no-cache
 
Host: node1.example.com:8181
 
Connection: keep-alive

now base64("container#root:VN9gDoGCnvL7HtgJ") == Y29udGFpbmVyI3Jvb3Q6Vk45Z0RvR0Nudkw3SHRnSg==

What's interesting, that incorrect Authorization header is last, while the correct one is before Accept.

ENTESB-2175
ENTESB-2171
https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/WAGON-416

Final solution (workaround?)

Here's what I did to get to this point:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.1       true        default                                            success

1. update bin/setenv

export JAVA_PERM_MEM=256M
 
export JAVA_MAX_MEM=1024M

2. update etc/system.properties

http.proxyUser=fuse
 
http.proxyPassword=fuse
 
http.proxyHost=javelin
 
http.proxyPort=3128
 
http.nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*
 
https.proxyUser=fuse
 
https.proxyPassword=fuse
 
https.proxyHost=javelin
 
https.proxyPort=3128
 
https.nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*

The above will configure correct behavior of sun.net.www.protocol.http.HttpURLConnection used by default by URL.openConnection.

3. start Fuse and create fabric

4. update io.fabric8.maven PID in fabric profile

I did it using hawtio. Make sure to use correct property names:

proxyProtocol=http
 
proxyHost=javelin
 
proxyPort=3128
 
proxyUsername=fuse
 
proxyPassword=fuse
 
nonProxyHosts=192.168.122.*|localhost|node1|node1.*|node2|node2.*

5 do not update org,ops4j.pax.url.mvn PID in default profile

As this will break http authentication used by GitDataStore (ENTESB-2175)

6. Create version 1.1 and patch it

JBossFuse:karaf@root> fabric:version-create --parent 1.0 1.1
 
Created version: 1.1 as copy of: 1.0
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> fabric:patch-apply --version 1.1 file:///opt/fuse/jboss-fuse-6.1.0.redhat-379-r1.zip

7. Update root container's version to 1.1

JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-upgrade 1.1 root
 
Upgraded container root from version 1.0 to 1.1
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success

8. Observe Squid logs

For example, I saw request for sshd-core-0.11.0.jar (using different Maven proxies), as the version in 6.1.0.redhat-379 is 0.9.0:

1415614696.758      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 4131 GET http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/sshd/sshd-core/0.11.0/sshd-core-0.11.0.jar - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.826      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 3782 CONNECT repo.fusesource.com:443 - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.828      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 3782 CONNECT repo.fusesource.com:443 - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.830      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 4221 GET http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/servicemix/m2-repo/org/apache/sshd/sshd-core/0.11.0/sshd-core-0.11.0.jar - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.832      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 4243 GET http://repository.springsource.com/maven/bundles/release/org/apache/sshd/sshd-core/0.11.0/sshd-core-0.11.0.jar - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.834      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 4247 GET http://repository.springsource.com/maven/bundles/external/org/apache/sshd/sshd-core/0.11.0/sshd-core-0.11.0.jar - HIER_NONE/- text/html
 
1415614696.836      0 192.168.122.108 TCP_DENIED/407 3770 CONNECT oss.sonatype.org:443 - HIER_NONE/- text/html

9. Create SSH container on different host:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-create-ssh --host 192.168.122.109 --user ggrzybek --private-key /home/ggrzybek/.ssh/id_rsa --pass-phrase *** ssh1
 
The following containers have been created successfully:
 
	Container: ssh1.
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.0       true        default                                            success

10. Update remote container

JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-upgrade 1.1 ssh1 
Upgraded container ssh1 from version 1.0 to 1.1
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.1       true        default                                            upgrading
 
...
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.1       true        default                                            downloading
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.1       false       default                                            installing
 
...
 
JBossFuse:karaf@root> container-list
 
[id]                           [version] [connected] [profiles]                                         [provision status]
 
root*                          1.1       true        fabric, fabric-ensemble-0000-1                     success
 
ssh1                           1.1       true        default                                            success

When I did container-connect ssh1 I could confirm, that the versions of bundles used where changed from -379 to -394.

Final notes

  • I saw that the changes made to etc/system.properties were lost after container upgrade
  • To make osgi:install work on SSH container, you have to fix etc/system.properties by adding http.proxy* properties with your HTTP proxy configuration.
  • I'm aware that this is not perfect solution, but it works. Some issues will be addressed with Fuse 6.2 release
Kevin Boone could you verify my suggestions?

changes made to etc/system.properties were lost after container upgrade

This may be prevented by setting those system properties in io.fabric8.agent PID (of default profile) using system. prefix, like this:

system.http.proxyHost = host
 
...

ENTESB-2171 is actually problem of LightweightHttpWagon which causes either of these two problems when http.proxyHost (and related) system properties are set:

  • without this fix each use of LightweightHttpWagon disables the system-wide support for http proxy, so both fabric-agent and osgi:install mvn:xxx won't go through proxy at all
  • with this fix each use of LightweightHttpWagon disables the http(s).nonProxyHosts, so all in-between containers communication (e.g. git pull/push) will go through proxy

IMO the latter is less problematic issue and will be resolved as soon as http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/WAGON-414 is resolved.

ENTESB-2171 can only be resolved by the fix in WAGON....
That's why I'm investigating the possibility of using non-lightweight version of WAGON (using http-client 4)
Can you send me the logs from this failed container?

I'd be happy to have this bug closed
In the meantime I'm working on replacing lightweight version of wagon-http with a working one...

Finally I'm marking this as resolved.
Fix in 6.2 patch branch: https://github.com/jboss-fuse/fabric8/commit/49260a1cd5f505419b3f8e3e0ec6f8e1a6ef1afb

Summarizing:

  • the above comments provide solution/workaround
  • ENTESB-2171 is fixed in 6.1 patch branch too
  • for 6.2 both osgi:install mvn:x/x/x and operations via fabric-maven-proxy will use non-lightweight http-wagon, so no more messing with system properties
  • for 6.2 the only configuration needed will be done using io.fabric8.maven PID (no more org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn PID)
Can we close this and open a separate doc bug?

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
These steps must be carried out on a machine with no direct Internet access, but with access to an HTTP proxy that can reach the JBoss repositories. Important The HTTP proxy must not be able to request back on the machine where Fuse is installed, as this would defeat the purpose of routing everything through the proxy. In practice this means that you can't test by installing Squid (or whatever) on the same machine as Fuse.

In the following steps, please substitute the correct host and port of your proxy.

install Fuse 6.1.0 GA and download patch Rollup 1

Set maximum JVM memory in bin/setenv to at least 768m.

fabric:create --wait-for-provisioning
container-remove-profile root jboss-fuse-full
wait-for-provisioning
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.host=squid.corp.redhat.com fabric
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.port=3128 fabric
fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/proxy.protocol=http fabric
fabric:profile-edit --pid 'io.fabric8.maven/proxy.nonProxyHosts=192.*|127.*|localhost|localhost.localdomain' fabric
wait-for-provisioning
fabric:version-create --parent 1.0 1.1
fabric:patch-apply --version 1.1 file:///tmp//path/to/rollup/1.zip
container-upgrade 1.1 root

Having carried out these steps – which sometimes seem to need a number of restarts to get to completion – various operations fail. For example, container-create-ssh fails with the following exception:

"Downloading Maven Artifact with groupId: io.fabric8 artifactId: fabric8-karaf and version: 1.0.0.redhat-394 from repository: https://repo.fusesource.com/nexus/content/repositories/snapshots/
Using URL: https://repo.fusesource.com/nexus/content/repositories/snapshots/io/fabric8/fabric8-karaf/1.0.0.redhat-394/fabric8-karaf-1.0.0.redhat-394.zip
Download failed with code: 000"

If an existing ensemble is patched, then containers that previously worked sometimes get stuck in the "downloading" state or the "failed" state. There are various other instances of erratic behaviour that are hard to describe in detail.

Looking the logs for the Squid proxy, we can see that once Rollup 1 is installed, not further operations are made on the proxy. However, without Rollup 1 we see that operations like container-create-ssh result in a number of HTTP operations through the proxy:

10.5.10.35 - - [18/Oct/2014:18:11:00 +1100] "CONNECT repo.fusesource.com:443 HTTP/1.1" 200 - "-" "Java/1.7.0_51"

We surmise, therefore, that installing Rollup 1 breaks HTTP proxy access to remote Maven proxies
